Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Towards Complete MAV Control Using Arrays of Synthetic Jets: Preliminary Study

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project investigates the development of flow/flight control system for a fixed-wing micro air vehicle (MAV) operating in a gusty urban environment, by using a carefully distributed array of zero-net-mass-flux (ZNMF) synthetic-jet actuators. A detailed analysis of a target scenario is provided as the primary motivation for the proposed efforts. Critical issues in the MAV flow, flight stability and propulsion MAV are identified. A high-fidelity numerical approach is proposed for addressing a number of fundamental issues related to (i) accurate modeling of synthetic jet micro-flows including scaling effects, (ii) elucidating effectiveness of synthetic jets for control of highly separated unsteady MAV flows at low Reynolds numbers, and (iii) examining the possibility of using reduced-order models of synthetic jets for future multi-disciplinary design optimization studies. Additionally, the project efforts include supervision of student teams in developing a Matlab Simulink environment for design of controlled MAV flight envelope using low-order representation of arrays of synthetic jets with tailored phase alignment and frequencies to produce adequate forces and moments. This work will lay foundation for follow-up collaborative efforts on MAV flow, flight stability and thrust control modeling, multi-disciplinary design optimization, micro-manufacturing, and eventual testing of the vehicle prototype.

Advancing the state-of-the-art of the micro air vehicle flight control technology, addressing fundamental flow control issues at the level of interacting jet micro flows and highly unsteady, separated grazing macro flows, and ensuring strong participation of undergraduate and graduate students in challenging design tasks constitute the primary intellectual merits of the proposed plan. As an educational merit, the planned activities will significantly enhance the offered design curriculum by introducing new advanced topics with focus on analysis, design, and optimization of micro air vehicle systems.

In its broader impact, the integrated plan will contribute to creating a research team environment in the predominantly teaching university, will involve a significant number of undergraduate (including female and minority) students in advanced research projects, and will pave the way to the proposed multi-university collaboration effort involving simulations and design of a MAV prototype equipped with arrays of synthetic jets for complete control of the vehicle.

Recent years have seen breakthrough advances in microfabrication and neural networks that provided a foundation for possibility of efficient active flow control using distributed arrays of micro-sensors and micro-actuators. Such micro-devices are viewed as having the potential of saving billions of dollars for aerospace industry annually through lift enhancement, drag reduction, noise suppression, icing mitigation, etc.  Our research focused on one particularly promising type of such micro-devices, namely a synthetic micro-jet actuator (SJA) with zero net mass fluxes (alternatively called a ZNMF actuator) schematically shown for the most basic configuration in Fig.1. This device has been actively investigated over the last decade for aircraft flow control.  At the bottom of the cavity, the excited membrane oscillates causing periodic entrainment and expulsion of the fluid through the orifice. Under certain conditions, a series of vortex rings formed during the expulsion phase are able to escape the reverse injection and convect away from the orifice thus forming a time-averaged jet.  During the oscillation period, the ejected and injected mass of flow is balanced while momentum is not, which thus produces time-averaged jet thrust. The maximum velocities of the jet may reach 100-200 m/sec based on different design estimates.  

The primary motivation in our research was to explore, using high-fidelity methods of numerical analysis, how such devices could be employed in MAV design. For example, distributed arrays of such micro-jet actuators could completely eliminate moving parts (such as ailerons) thus greatly enhancing manoeuvrability required for small air vehicles operating in tight urban environments. Fast response times could also help in mitigating gust effects thus improving flight stability and controls. Another subject of research was examining feasibility of using such arrays to produce enough thrust for MAV.

The project involved a group of faculty and students at Embry-Riddle focusing on various aspects of the project tasks and its extensions. For example, one group developed high-fidelity analyses of MAV operation in gusty urban environments focusing on canonical flow-structure interaction problems. Other groups conducted simulations to explore embedded SJA impacts on such flows, as well as possible means of reducing emitted airfoil noise. The context of icing control using thermally-activated synthetic jets is another subject being currently investigated using high-accuracy numerical tools. Mathematical modeling of efficient feedback loop controls for such devices involved in various tasks was also part of the research activities. Our experimental group now employs low-fidelity tools (such as lumped-element models) to design and manufacture such micro-actuators, test and calibrate them in our low-speed wind tunnel, and conduct flight testing as part of flight control studies. Finally, as an outreach of the project and its additional educational activity, a collaboration of engineering and business major undergardaute students developed a business plan for technology transfer of the project ideas.

Overall, the conducted preliminary studies addressed feasibility of flow, flight and thrust controls of MAVs using wing-embedded SJAs. We developed a methodology combining low- and high-fidelity analyses to estimate SJA impact on all three components, plus added assessment of SJA effect on airfoil acoustic and icing control (in progress). Particularly important was incorporating a model of the embedded SJA actuator into high-fidelity analyses of gust-airfoil interactions that allowed observing SJA effectiveness at various operating conditions characterized by frequency and amplitude of micro-jet excitation.
